awd_titl_txt: Miscibility-immiscibility conundrum in air-liquid-vapor flow modeling: Bridging the gap by using the phase-field method
awd_abstract_narration:
Mixtures of air, liquid water, and water vapor are ubiquitous in nature and in engineering processes.  These mixtures occur in energy generation, transport of marine vehicles, inhalation drug therapies, and in cloud formation in the atmosphere.  Currently, there is no general theory to describe the fluid dynamics behavior of these mixtures, which limits a wide range of scientific and technological advances. This research will develop a first-principles-based computational model that will provide a theoretical framework for understanding the physics of air, liquid water, and water vapor mixtures. The investigators will use highly controlled experiments to provide physical insights and validate the computational method. This research will deliver interdisciplinary advancements at the interface of engineering, mathematics, and physics. The research broader impacts will be complemented by outreach and educational activities.  These include an initiative to reshape the way fluid mechanics is introduced to undergraduate students and recruiting and retention activities for groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields.

Multiphase flow dynamics has received significant attention from the scientific community due to the captivating physics produced by the interplay of miscibility, inertial forces, viscous forces, and surface tension. While there has been significant progress in understanding single-component, two-phase flows (e.g., vaporization and condensation of a single chemical species), and single-phase, two-component flows (for example, bubbly flows composed of air and water), the dynamics of flows involving simultaneously two phases and two components are not well understood. This project will develop a new first-principles-based computational model that captures all physical factors relevant to air, liquid water, and water vapor flows. The model will be validated through state-of-the-art experiments monitoring the interface dynamics, velocity and pressure fields in three dimensions. The model will be based on the phase-field theory that allows a natural transition between miscible (air and water vapor) and immiscible (air and liquid water) mixtures, providing an ideal enabling theoretical framework. The integrated computational and experimental research to be developed in this project promises to constitute a leap forward in our ability to investigate flows involving air, liquid water, and water vapor and will provide the enabling tools for transformative advances across numerous engineering and science applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The term multiphase flow is generically used for flows that involve several phases or states of matter (i.e., vapor, liquid, or solid) and/or several components (i.e., materials with different chemical properties but in the same phase). While significant progress has been made in understanding single-component, two-phase flows (e.g., liquid water-water vapor flows present in boiling and cavitation) and single-phase, two-component flows (e.g., air-water systems such as bubbly flows), our predictive capabilities to simulate the dynamics of flows involving simultaneously two-phases and two-components remain limited.

The overarching objective of this project was to develop a new mathematical model for air-liquid-vapor flows that accounts for liquid-vapor transformations and the associated miscibility change with respect to air using phase-field theory. Air-liquid-vapor flows are crucial to understanding the behavior of clouds in the atmosphere, the impact and penetration of cavitating objects through a water-air free-surface, and the effectiveness of inhalation drug therapy. In a broader context, this work filled an important gap in scientific knowledge pertaining to the modeling and simulation capabilities to study flows involving two phases and two components simultaneously. The model was validated against innovative, highly controlled experiments and theoretical predictions. An important finding of this project is that phase-field models can accurately and fundamentally predict the complex dynamics of flows involving multiple phases and multiple components, including non-equilibrium thermodynamics and non-equilibrium phase change based on non-convex potentials. An important feature of the phase-field approach is that it reduces the level of empiricism usually required to model liquid-vapor phase change. We showed that the Navier-Stokes-Cahn-Hilliard equations are a robust and reliable model for flows involving two fluid components. We also proved that the Navier-Stokes-Korteweg equations can be used as a first-principles model for single-component two-phase flows, and we developed a new phase-field theory for flows that involve two phases and two components that may be understood as a thermodynamically-consistent combination of the two aforementioned models. To validate the models, we developed new experimental capabilities for performing time-resolved volumetric particle image velocimetry (PIV) in bubbly flows to resolve the three-dimensional character of the underlying phenomena. This effort involved the development of experimental setups, optimizations of the imaging configurations, and experiments to develop tomographic PIV processing approaches.

Multiphase and multicomponent flows, such as those studied here, are ubiquitous in engineering, science, and medicine. We anticipate potential impacts in medical imaging and drug delivery. Thus, the basic science developed in this project can have a strong impact on the aforementioned disciplines and boost the US economy and technological leadership.

In addition, this project educated graduate and undergraduate students by training them in advanced modeling techniques for fluid dynamics, advanced computational methods, and innovative experimental methods combined with rigorous data analysis.
